name: temperature table
explanation: Temperatures for environment and material tables.
structure: Produces entries for different types of genres and worlds. The 'common' and 'rare' tables are generic and should be compatible with almost any world. To retain compatibility with most settings, the  non-generic tables should be called only from other tables by specifying their name directly. Some subtables intentionally overlap.

tables.name: mythological
tables.explanation: Imaginary temperatures once rumoured to have existed.

tables.name: rare mythological
tables.explanation: Rare imaginary temperatures once rumoured to have existed.

tables.name: rare fantasy
tables.explanation: Rare imaginary temperatures for fantasy worlds.
entries: as hot as the paraelemental plane of ice
as hot as the elemental plane of fire

tables.name: modern
entries: the temperature of an incandescent light bulb (2000 °C)

tables.name: futuristic
tables.explanation: Imaginary temperatures for science fiction worlds.
entries: the temperature of the cosmic microwave background (−270.424 °C)
the temperature of a lightning bolt (28,000 °C)

tables.name: rare futuristic
tables.explanation: Rare imaginary temperatures for science fiction worlds.
entries: the temperature of Sun's core (16 million °C)
the temperature produced by a thermonuclear weapon (350 million °C)
the temperatures procuded by a high frequency electromagnetic wave generator (2 billion °C)
the temperature of the core of a dying high-mass star (3 billion °C)
the temperature of a merging binary neutron star system (350 billion °C)
the temperature of a heavy ion collision (1 trillion °C)
the temperature of a proton vs nucleus collision (10 trillion °C)
the temperature of the Big Bang (1.4E32 °C)
